newsitem.title: GHANA: Standard Chartered Ghana assets up 53 pct.
newsitem.headline: Standard Chartered Ghana assets up 53 pct.

text.p: The financial results of Ghana's four major commercial banks show that Standard Chartered Bank of Ghana posted the fastest growth in 1996.

Compared with the 1995 results, SCBG's total assets soared by 53 percent to 359 billion cedis ($190 million), total liabilities went up 49 percent to 317 billion, shareholders' funds 91 percent to 41 billion and profit-after-tax 74 percent to 27 billion cedis.
SCBG with capital of 0.5 billion cedis, is the smallest of the four major banks.

Standard Chartered Group U.K. holds 60 percent of shares in SCBG. The remaining shares are held by the public, 22.915 percent, foreign institutional investors, 15.620 percent, and the government, 1.465 percent.

Ghana Commercial Bank's -- the largest of the banks with capital of 20 billion cedis and 706 billion cedis of total assets -- growth lagged the others. Total assets grew 26 percent to 706 billion cedis, total liabilities 27 percent to 627 billion, shareholders' funds went up 16 percent to 79 billion and profit after tax was 40 billion cedis, down five percent compared with 1995.

Ghana Commercial Bank went public in March last year. In November, Denko Industrial Corp Berhad of Malaysia took a 40 percent stake and has started taking over management of GCB. Of the remaining shares, the public holds 42 percent and the government 18 percent.

Social Security Bank, with capital of 6.7 billion cedis, had a good year, with total assets up 51 percent to 386 billion cedis, total liabilities up 52 percent to 333 billion, shareholders' funds up 48 percent to 53 billion and profit after tax up 58 percent to 26 billion.

Last February, a consortium led by London-based Blakeney Management Ltd took a 40 percent stake in the Social Security Bank. The remaining shares, representing 33.61 percent of equity, are held by the quasi-government entity, Social Security and National Investment Trust. Public shareholders own 21.09 percent, while the government directly holds a 5.30 percent slice.

Barclays Bank of Ghana, capitalised at one billion cedis, saw its total assets rise 51 percent to 345 billion, total liabilitites were up 50 percent to 310 billion, shareholders' funds 58 percent to 36 billion and profit after tax rose 42 percent to 16 billion. The government holds 60 percent of shares in Barclays Bank of Ghana, while the remaining 40 percent is held by Barclays Bank Plc of the U.K.
